CatDescriptText: Cutline of images published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, September 7, 1940 reads: "Where Uncle Sam Is Training Negro Soldiers in Art Of Anti-Aircraft Defense - Here are some scenes of Fort Bragg, where Negro soldiers are being trained for coastal artillery service for the first time in history. Top, left, is a view of one of the many streets.  The buildings are mess halls (note soldiers at right in line for dinner).  Top, center: Some of the mechanized machinery they will use in the Coast Artillery.  Lower left: A section of the tents in which the majority of new recruits are staying until modern barracks are built.  Top, right: View inside a tent.  Two men sleep in each tent.  Bottom right: Five of the sergeants who have been sent to Fort Bragg by the Army to help train the new recruits.  They were all formerly with the 25th Infantry.  Left to right: I. Dunham, L. Jones, Ralph Johnson, Thomas Thompson and Robert Page. - All photos by Harris."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of Army sergeants, from left: I. Dunham, L. Jones, Ralph Johnson, Thomas Thompson and Robert Page, standing and saluting at Fort Bragg, North Carolina
